entry.title: ‘Glee’ star Matthew Morrison works tirelessly to drive overbearing ‘Finding Neverland’
entry.summary: Matthew Morrison and Kelsey Grammer in "Finding Neverland."

entry.title: East-West Link payout obscene: Morrison
entry.summary: "For the Victorian government to spend $420 million to pay to a company not to build a road is an obscenity," Mr Morrison told reporters in the NSW Illawarra region.

entry.title: 'Glee' star Matthew Morrison finds himself back on Broadway
entry.summary: While he's been away from New York, Morrison has seen the profile of Broadway and theater increase, in part due to shows like "Glee" and "Smash."

entry.title: 'Glee' star Matthew Morrison finds himself back on Broadway
entry.summary:
Morrison, who played choir teacher Will Schuester for six season on "Glee," is starring in "Finding Neverland," a musical directed by Diane Paulus that explores the Peter Pan book's back story.

Morrison had previously starred on Broadway in "Hairspray," ''South Pacific" and "The Light in the Piazza," for which he was nominated for a 2005 Tony Award.

entry.title: 'Glee' star Matthew Morrison finds himself back on Broadway
entry.summary:
NEW YORK (AP) - It's taken six years for Matthew Morrison to get back on Broadway so it's no surprise he knows a thing or two about where he ended up.

"I just imagine her welcome guests back in her pearls and everything," Morrison said, sipping tea.

Morrison, 36, plays J.M. Barrie, the "Peter Pan" author, in the adaptation from the 2004 whimsical film of the same name about a widow whose four young sons inspired Barrie to write the children's classic.

"There's nothing more challenging or exciting than doing a brand new Broadway show," said Morrison.

The show ended earlier this year and Morrison's last scene was of him singing "Teach Your Children" by Crosby Stills, Nash & Young in dedication to all his fictional students, many who are in tears by the end of the song.

Morrison barely had time to say goodbye to Schuester before it was time to tackle Barrie.

entry.title: Van Morrison on 'Re-Working the Catalogue' with an all-star lineup
entry.summary:
That number increased with Monday's release of Morrison's new album, "Duets: Re-Working the Catalogue."

Among his 16 duet partners: Mavis Staples, Taj Mahal, Michael Buble, Natalie Cole, the late Bobby Womack and Morrison's daughter, Shana Morrison.

For Morrison, "There were two parts to it," the 69-year-old artist told The Times in an exclusive email interview.

Morrison has spent the vast majority of his career looking ahead, writing and recording a string of studio albums that now numbers more than three dozen; "Duets: Re-Working the Catalogue" represents a rare dip into his past.

During that event, Morrison invited Staples, Womack and Cole to go into a recording studio to get the ball rolling.

"I first heard him in the '60s at a show with Aretha Franklin and Dr. John and I thought then, 'Who is this guy?'" Mahal told The Times at a performance Morrison gave last summer outside his hometown of Belfast.
